snippet: The corporation established elaborate procedures that placed more formal responsibility for delicate decisions in the hands not of individual managers, but of rigid hierarchies.
abstract: British Broadcasting Corporation established elaborate procedures in 2004 to address crisis over journalistic standards, but bureaucracy made organization even more unwieldy; these very structures seem to have failed in latest BBC scandal, in which its news division first canceled child abuse segment it should have broadcast, and later broadcast one it should have canceled.

byline.original: By SARAH LYALL and NICHOLAS KULISH
byline.contributor: Matthew Purdy contributed reporting from New York, and Lark Turner from London.

lead_paragraph: The corporation established elaborate procedures that placed more formal responsibility for delicate decisions in the hands not of individual managers, but of rigid hierarchies.

headline.seo: BBC Failures Show Limits of Guidelines
headline.main: Crises at BBC Brought Rules, Then a Failure
